Graphical abstract The world is using lot of fossil fuels due to increase in energy demand. This results in high production of CO2 which is the main reason for global warming and harmful for the environment. These issues have driven the scientists to develop environment friendly alternative energies to replace these harmful fuels. Hydrogen has become one of the most promising fuels which are environment friendly and sustainable. To produce this green and clean source of energy, electrochemical water splitting has become one of the most suitable routes. For the efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) an active catalyst is required to achieve high conversion efficiency. Many catalysts have been reported in the literature for hydrogen production through different methods. But Molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) has attracted a lot of attention and attraction to produce hydrogen through HER due to its high surface activity and electrochemical properties. In this review, the recent research progress has been reported on the Mo2C for HER mechanism. Different methods for the synthesis of Mo2C and its hybrid has been discussed extensively, along with different strategies to modify the physicochemical properties of Mo2C and its hybrid. Furthermore, the application of Mo2C related to its activity, durability, activation, and deactivation mechanism of the catalyst are critically reviewed. It is concluded that by the addition of another component in Mo2C can enhance the activity of the catalyst and gives more conversion rate. Hence, it realizes that Mo2C certainly can be used as an alternative catalyst for hydrogen production via water splitting. Water splitting Oxygen reduction reaction 1 Introduction 1.1 Why the need of renewable source of energy In the past few decades, the consumption of fossil fuels increased due to increase in the demand for energy. This created many environmental issues resulting in increased interest in the research and development of alternative renewable energy sources [1–3]. Due to utilization of the fossil fuels, carbon dioxide is produced which is considered as the main contributor to the greenhouse gas effect and climate changes. In the recent decades, intense industrial revolution and increase in world’s population have led to the rapid consumption of fossil fuels which increased the concentration of CO2 in the environment [4]. Increased energy consumption and decline of natural energy resources have led to intensification in the interest of environment friendly methodologies [5–7]. Today, across the globe, access to renewable, sustainable and green sources of energy is the main concern which encouraged us to explore the renewable energy alternatives from sustainable technologies [8–11]. Among all the proposed solutions for these relating problems, synthesis of hydrogen as a clean fuel is most competent and sustainable green process. Efficiently harvested and stored solar energy can fulfill our energy needs in the form of solar energy cells, and photo electrocatalytic water splitting by converting the water into hydrogen using sunlight [10,12,13]. In this regard, electrochemical water splitting is considered to be one of the most promising solutions for the production of hydrogen as a clean and carbon-neutral source of energy with high energy storage capacity [14–16]. Many different technologies such as water-alkali or proton exchange membrane electrolyzers, solar water splitting devices have been developed for the production of pure hydrogen gas [17–19]. However, about 95 % of the hydrogen is still being produced by the steam methane reforming and coal gasification for the industrial use. These required a huge amount of fossil fuels, producing a lot of greenhouse gases mainly carbon dioxide [20]. The introduction to the fuel cell technology has huge reduction in the emissions of greenhouse gases. The fuel cells powered by hydrogen obtained from solar energy are capable of reducing the emissions of these gases nearly up to zero [21]. From renewable energy sources, water electrolysis has a great contribution to the production of hydrogen, a clean and carbon-neutral energy carrier [22,23]. Hydrogen is considered to be the most important fuel for the future and production of hydrogen by water splitting has been proposed as an ideal clean fuel [24]. It is the most promising candidate because of its high energy storage capacity from renewable sources [13,25]. Hydrogen has many potential applications such as powering the non-polluting vehicles, domestic heating and as air craft fuel [26]. It is considered to be a good alternative to conventional carbon-based fossil fuels due to its high energy density, zero emissions, renewability and emits only water as a by-product without any carbon emission [27,28]. The energy density of hydrogen is about two times greater than the typical solid fuels [28,29]. Globally, the production of hydrogen is near about 500 billion cubic meters per year. Recently hydrogen is produced from oil about 18 %, natural gas 48 %, coal 11 % and water electrolysis about 4 % globally [30,31]. The hydrogen produced is mainly used in many industries such as petroleum refining processes, petrochemicals industries, fuel cells and many other chemical industries [28,32]. Hydrogen has several other benefits like high specific energy on mass basis i.e. 9.5 kg of hydrogen is equal to 25 kg of gasoline, it can easily be transported than natural gas. Moreover it contains only H atom so that is neither toxic nor greenhouse gas that can pollute the environment [33,34]. 1.2 Electrochemical water splitting reactions Water splitting by electrolysis to produce hydrogen and oxygen is an eco-friendly, sustainable and high-performance method for hydrogen evolution reaction, attracting great attention in the last couple of decades [20,35]. It is a suitable process for the production of hydrogen as it uses water as a resource and produces only pure hydrogen as main and pure oxygen as a by-product [28]. This technique possesses remarkable properties such as high sensitivity, fast response time, low cost, simple instrumentation, possible miniaturization and easily portable devices [36]. In this process, water splits into oxygen along with complementary proton and electron at the anode. On the other hand, hydrogen gas evolves at the cathode due to the combination of electrons and protons. High energy conversion, low environmental effects and wide range of practical application make this technology very attractive [37,38]. Water splitting involves two simultaneous processes i.e. hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The former occurs at the cathode and the latter occurs at the anode [39]. Hydrogen evolution is one of the most widely investigated electrochemical reactions due to its complicated kinetics. During HER three different processes are occurring at electrode surface such as adsorption, chemical and electrochemical recombination. These are called Volmer, Tafel and Heyrovsky's steps respectively occur simultaneously at electrode surface [40–42]. Water electrolysis can be classified into the four categories based on the type of electrolyte used, operating conditions and ionic agents such as OH−, H+, O−2. However, the principle remains the same. These four types of electrolysis methods are [28]; a Alkaline water electrolysis b Solid oxide electrolysis c Microbial electrolysis d PEM water electrolysis Alkaline water electrolysis was first introduced by Dieman and Troostwijk in 1789. It is a well-established method to produce hydrogen. In this process, initially at the cathode, two molecules of alkaline solution (KOH/NaOH) were reduced to the hydrogen where one molecule produces two OH− ions. Hydrogen produced will be liberated from the cathode side in gaseous form whereas OH− (under the influence of the electrical circuit between anode and cathode) will be transferred to the anode side through porous diaphragm and O2 will be liberated at the anode. Alkaline electrolysis works at low temperatures with an aqueous solution (KOH/NaOH) as electrolyte [28]. Solid oxide electrolysis is a well-known technology to produce hydrogen was studied by the Donitz and Erdle in the 1980s. Solid oxide electrolysis has gained a lot of attention due to the production of ultra-pure hydrogen by the transformation of electrical energy into chemical energy with greater efficiency. This process operates at high temperatures, pressure and uses water in the form of steam [28,43]. Microbial electrolysis is also receiving interest to produce hydrogen by using organic matter such as renewable biomass and wastewater. This process is closely related to microbial fuel cells but with the opposite principle. Microbial electrolysis was first introduced by two research organizations i.e. Penn state university and Wageningen University in 2005 [44]. In this process, hydrogen is produced by the organic matter under the influence of electrical energy. Initially, at the anode side, the substrate oxidized (by the microbial action), which produces electrons and protons. These electrons will move towards the cathode side by the external circuit and protons will move towards the cathode through the proton conduction membrane. These protons and electrons will combine at the cathode and produces hydrogen [28,45]. Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) electrolysis was developed in 1966 to overcome the drawbacks of alkaline water electrolysis. It was first introduced by Grubb in early fifties and is like PEM fuel cell technology in which solid polysulfonated membranes were used as an electrolyte. This proton exchange membrane has many benefits such as lower gas permeability, high proton conductivity, compact design and high-pressure operation [28]. The main catalyst used for the PEM electrolysis is highly active noble metals i.e. Pt/Pd as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at cathode and IrO2/RuO2 as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at anode [28,46]. The HER works as a two-electron transfer mechanism. In the acidic solution, the mechanism is initiated by Volmer Reaction through which hydronium ions are evolved to form the intermediates of hydrogen (H*) absorbed on the surface of electrode. Similarly, for the alkaline solution, water molecule act as source of proton. Subsequently, the hydrogen molecule is produced through two different ways depending on the hydrogen intermediates (H*) surface coverage. If the coverage of the intermediates is high, then the rate limiting step will be the Tafel step in which two adjacent intermediates combine to form a hydrogen molecule (H2). When the coverage of the intermediate is low, then the Heyrovsky reaction will dominate in which single intermediate will attract the electron and proton in the acidic medium simultaneously and in alkaline or basic medium will attract the water molecule and electron [47–49]. Water splitting occurs when energy provided is high enough to meet the potential requirements and to overcome the over potential and losses [50]. Based on the water-splitting electrolysis the electrode reactions can be chemically expressed in the following different ways [51]; In acidic solution (1) C a t h o d e R e a c t i o n 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 (2) A n o d e R e a c t i o n H 2 O → 2 H + + 0.5 O 2 + 2 e - In neutral and alkaline solutions (3) C a t h o d e R e a c t i o n 2 H 2 O + 2 e - → H 2 + 2 O H - (4) A n o d e R e a c t i o n 2 O H - → H 2 O + 0.5 O 2 + 2 e - Hydrogen dissociation and desorption are the main steps for hydrogen production as seen from above reactions [51,52]. The hydrogen adsorption free energy is related to the hydrogen evolving mechanism of the catalyst. For a good HER catalyst, the free energy must be approaching to zero. This is due to the weak adsorption leading towards the poor interaction between the protons and the electrode surface. On the other hand, the high free energy will make it difficult to break the bond between hydrogen and catalyst surface [47,53]. Similarly, oxygen evolution reaction is also a four-electrode process. In the acidic medium, water oxidizes into oxygen and hydrogen while in the neutral or alkaline solution, the hydroxyl ion oxidizes into water and oxygen. The process is expressed as in the given equations: In the acidic medium (5) H 2 O + * → H O * + H + + e - (6) H O * → O * + H + + e - (7) O * + H 2 O → H O O * + H * + e - (8) H O O * → * + O 2 + H + + e - In the basic medium (9) O H - + * → H O * + e - (10) H O * + O H - → O * + H 2 O + e - (11) O * + O H - → H O O - + e - (12) H O O * + O H - → * + O 2 + H 2 O + e - Where * is used to denote the active surface area of the catalyst. In OER mechanism the step with the highest energy barrier become the potential determining step. For the ideal catalyst the thermodynamically free energy is to be 1.23 eV [47]. 1.3 Role of molybdenum carbide as a catalyst for electrochemical water splitting Electrochemical water splitting is one of the promising methods to produce hydrogen. It is the most convenient strategy for renewable and sustainable energy production by employing earth-abundant transition metals as a catalysts and water as feedstock [54]. However, the process is of the sluggish kinetics for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction. Therefore an electrocatalyst is required to enhance the rate of these electrochemical reactions [22]. Over the past few years, a lot of research has been done in the development of materials that can be used as electrocatalysts [8,55]. Various semi-conductor materials have been developed to produce hydrogen gas from water splitting such as CdS, ZnCdS and C3N4, etc. [56,57]. The hydrogen evolution by water electrolysis depends upon the efficient catalyst that must be stable and competent to reduce water at a low potential level [25,58]. For this reason, the key factor is to reduce the cost of the catalyst and to increase the energy conversion proficiency by altering the nature of the catalyst [54]. Platinum is known to be one of the most efficient electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution, but due to its high cost and scarcity, it is not suitable at large scale [59,60]. Therefore, for large scale production of hydrogen an inexpensive metal to replace the platinum is required. Transition metals are really capable for this application as they have vacant d-orbitals that play a very important role for a moderate hydrogen bond which is very crucial for the hydrogen production [61]. Many efforts have been made to develop an efficient catalyst to produce hydrogen which is robust and potent; translating as two important parameters, the overpotential and catalytic efficiency is highly sought after [24,62]. Catalysts of different categories were developed and used for water splitting but the high yield of hydrogen could not be achieved [63,64]. Many efforts have been made to use transition metal phosphides, nitrides, and carbides as a promising noble metal free catalyst for the hydrogen evolution reactions [65]. Transition metals carbides are formed by inserting carbon atom in the lattice of the transition atoms. These carbides have generated much importance due to their unique chemical bonding and lattice structures. The carbide compounds showed improved properties as compared to the parent metals and their oxides. Based upon the unique chemical bonding and properties these carbides are categorized into different classes such as salinic compounds, intermediate compounds, and interstitial compounds. Yet, at relatively low temperatures the first two have shown instability as they decompose easily by water. The third category i.e. interstitial compounds have shown unique behavior due to the chemical bonding of the carbon and the transition metal atoms [33,66].These type of carbides possess high melting point, hardness, tensile strength and also showed high electric and thermal conductivity that are comparable to the ceramics and other noble metals. Mo based compounds retain similar behavior like platinum for the hydrogen evolution reactions. In the last few years Mo2C family has emerged as most promising competitor for HER [67,68]. Mo2C and MoS2 can be used instead of noble Pt catalyst due to their effective HER activity, low cost and high availability [69,70]. Particularly Molybdenum carbide have shown higher activity for the HER as they have similar d-orbital structure and same electronic state to Pt in the Fermi level [68,71,72]. The combination of molybdenum with the carbon material has amplified the conductivity of Mo2C to great extent. Moreover, it also reduced the center of d-band in molybdenum through inducing the charge shift from molybdenum to carbon. This results in lowering of the Mo-H bond energy for hydrogen desorption [73–75]. It is important to mention that the electrochemical properties of Mo2C depends upon the surface area, crystal phase and also the surface composition [76]. In Molybdenum carbide three different types of bonding exists; one is the rearrangement of the metal-metal bonds called metallic bonding, second one is bond formation between metal and non-metals called covalent bond and third one is ionic bonds due to the transfer of the electrons [33,77,78]. Because of having the properties of covalent compounds, ionic crystals and transition metals, molybdenum carbide shows Pt-like behavior in many catalytic reactions such as electro-catalysis, heterogeneous catalysis, and some other selective hydrogenation processes. Different geometrical and electronic structures of Mo2C influences its catalytic activity and performance [79,80]. Addition of the carbon atom in the transition metals i.e. tungsten and molybdenum lattice may be effective for the electro negativity of the metals [33]. Comparing with other compounds interstitial transition compounds have shown more stable properties under the humid and low temperature conditions. Unique and stable properties of these transition compounds are associated to their electronic and crystalline structures. The metal atom in the lattice of the transition compounds are in three different forms which are face centered cubic, hexagonal closed packed and simple hexagonal structures. In these compounds, the carbon atoms are in the interstitial sites as shown in the Fig. 1 [33,81,82]. Different crystalline phases of Mo2C are present such as cubic γ-Mo2C, hexagonal α-Mo2C and orthorhombic β-Mo2C phase. Earlier it was believed that cubic and hexagonal were considered to be the best active catalyst but recent development shows that the orthorhombic is considered more efficient for developing activities [83,84]. Hybrid of Mo2C has also engrossed lot of importance such as Mo2C coated with graphitic carbon sheets was reported by the Cui et al. which showed very good activity for the hydrogen production. In this covalent bonding of Mo2C with carbon allows the electrons to transfer which decreases the hydrogen binding energy in the HER process [85]. Another hybrid of Mo2C layered by the nitrogen-doped porous carbon was reported by Lu et al. which showed the lower Tafel slope and overpotential at given current density in the alkaline solutions. They revealed that it is due to the strong interactions between molybdenum carbide and nitrogen-doped porous carbon lowering the energy for water splitting [86]. 2 Materials and investigations 2.1 Preparation of pure Mo2C For the preparation of pure Mo2C catalyst, suitable precursors for solid carbon and of molybdenum was considered. About 1.2 g of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate was added in about 20 mL of DI water under room temperature with constant stirring for about 5 min. Adding a certain amount of prepared SiO2 in the above solution and ultrasonicate it for 30 min. This resulted in the formation of a uniform suspension followed by the addition of 0.4 g of dopamine hydrochloride in the suspension yielding a brick red solution. About 40 mL of ethanol was poured into the solution and stirred for 5 min. Adjust the pH at about 8.5–9 by injecting 0.4 mL of NH3.H2O quickly in the suspension. The mixture was stirred for about 2 h and orange red precipitates were obtained after centrifugation with many repetitive washing with DI water and absolute ethanol. Further, the precursor was heated at 800 °C for 3 h under the flow of argon with a ramping rate of temperature 5 °C/minute and then the sample is dried at 80 °C for 10 h as shown in the figure given below. Finally, the dried sample was leached on HF acid (20 %) for 30 min which completely removed the SiO2 spheres (schematic shown in Fig. 2 ) [87]. Another typical preparation of molybdenum carbide catalyst from the cornstalk was reported by Xing, J., et al. in which firstly the cornstalks were cut into very small pieces which were then boiled at about 100 °C in 1 M HCl solution. These acid etched cornstalks were then washed with distilled water till the pH of the solution became normal and neutral. Later, the solution was kept in the cool atmosphere in the refrigerator and further dried by freezing at -50 °C having a pressure of 20 Pa to yield a cornstalk precursor which was denoted as C-precursor. The precursor was then dipped in ammonium molybdate solution with magnetic string for 4 h to for attaining the intermediate which was called Mo-precursor. This Mo-precursor was subsequently dried by freezing just like the C-precursor. In the end, the Mo-precursor was carbonized at 900 °C under argon or hydrogen atmosphere for 3 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C/minute [88]. Li, T. et al. proposed a method for the preparation of Mo2C nanotubes using MoO3 nanorods. The prepared MoO3 nanorods were dispersed in 30 mL DI water and sonicated for 15 min. After sonication 300 mg of AHM and 75 mg of 3-hydroxytryptamine hydrochloride were gradually added into the above solution due to which the milky white solution turned into orange-red suspension. About 60 mL of absolute ethanol was added rapidly into the above solution and stirred for 5 min followed by the quick addition of 450 mL aq. NH3 under stirring for 2 h. Finally, the orange-red precipitates were filtered by suction filtration followed by washing with pure ethanol for some time. The precursor was dehydrated to room temperature for 12 h and was transferred to carbonization at 750 °C in an inert atmosphere under argon flow for 16 h at a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute. Finally, Mo2C nanotubes were obtained [89]. Similarly, Tang, C, et al. prepared pure Mo2C involving the source of molybdenum and carbon such as GLC in the ratio of 1:10, 1:20, 1:40, dissolving both in the DI water and mixing it for 10 min formed a homogenous mixture that was transferred to autoclave at about 200 °C for 10 h. After that, the solution was separated through centrifugation and dried which will give a black powder precursor that was loaded into the tube furnace for carbonization at 800 °C under an inert atmosphere at different durations. In the end, a black pure Mo2C powder was obtained [90]. Wyvratt, B.M. et al. reported a method for the preparation of molybdenum carbide through temperature reduction method using ammonium paramolybdate. Precursor was transferred into the quartz flow reactor which was supported by a bed of quartz wool in a vertical furnace. The sample was heated up to 350 °C in the flow of H2 at the slope rate of 5 °C/minute and maintained these conditions for 12 h. Followed by this about 15 % of CH4/H2 gas was injected and temperature increased up to 590 °C with the slope rate of 2.5 °C/minute and maintained the conditions for 2 h. After the completion, the furnace was cooled down to room temperature. Now the material was treated in the inert atmosphere to obtain pure Mo2C [91]. Vitale, G. et al. also discussed a method to produce pure Mo2C involving AHM as a molybdenum source and sucrose as a carbon source. Both were added in DI water and mixed in different concentrations under constant stirring for 15 min at normal temperature and dried the solution at 100 °C for 24 h. The dried powder was thermally treated in a fixed bed reactor under the flow of hydrogen gas first to reach a temperature of 250 °C and maintained for 24 h. In the second step, the temperature was increased up to 325 °C and again maintained it for 24 h. Then, again increased the temperature to 400 °C and kept for 72 h. when the reaction was completed, the material was cooled to room temperature in the inert atmosphere such as the flow of N2 gas [92]. Abd. Rahim Yacob, M.k.A et al. worked on the preparation of Mo2C and determined the effect of carbon on its activity. The experimental setup involved AHM that was dissolved in the DI water in a volumetric flask, added a small amount of carbon in it that was dispersed over the prepared AHM solution in the 3-neck round bottom flask. To create the inert atmosphere in the flask, nitrogen had flowed through the one side of the flask. In a modified microwave of power usage 800 W, microwave alloying was performed for about 2 min of radiation time. In the end, the product was washed with hot water and dried at up to 100 °C for one night [93]. Another method of preparation of pure Mo2C catalyst was discussed by the Schaidle, J.A. et al. who have synthesized the catalyst through temperature reduction method. The fabrication involved ammonium paramolybdate as a source of Mo that was crushed into a fine powder and loaded into a vertical tubular quartz reactor. The precursor was heated to 350 °C with a slope rate of 5 °C/minute under the flow of hydrogen gas, maintaining the temperature for about 12 h. After that, the gas was changed to 15 % CH4/H2 and increased the temperature to 590 °C with a slope rate of 2 °C/minute and maintained it for 2 h. Furthermore, product was cooled till room temperature to produce pure molybdenum carbide. Hybrids were also prepared by depositing the different metal via wet impregnation method. Different concentrations of Pd (NH3)4(NO3)2, H2PtCl6, Cu (NO3)2, CuCl2, Co(NO3)2 or FeCl2, etc. were dissolved into the DI water to make a solution. Complete deposition of the precursor was assumed, and Argon gas was flowed through the precursor for purging purpose. Finally, the precursor was transferred into the tube reactor under the Argon gas and reduced at 450 °C for about 4 h. The final product was stored in the glove box for subsequent characterization [94]. Wang, H., Z. et al. discussed effect of morphologies for the preparation of pure Mo2C. They introduced a typical procedure involving the AHM solution as a source of Mo dissolved with DI water. The solution was then mixed with PEG, PVP, CTAB, and SDBS to form a solution ensuring the molar ratios of carbon to molybdenum was fixed as 1:2. Ethanol was added dropwise under constant magnetic stirring that formed a homogenous mixture at room temperature. To maintain the pH at 4, a small amount of nitric acid was supplemented, and a milky white solution was obtained. The solution was then loaded into stainless steel autoclave heated at 220 °C for 6 h in the oven. After the reaction, the material was cooled down to room temperature, washed-out serval time, separated by filtration and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 4 h [95]. Another typical preparation of pure Mo2C was discussed by Zhe, F., et al. in which they prepared the catalyst by wet impregnation method. They used AHM as a precursor of Mo and activated carbon as source of carbon. First the activated carbon was crushed and sieved into 40–60 mesh. Then it was pretreated with 1 M HNO3 for 8 h at 80 °C, filtered and washed with distilled water to normalize the pH and was dried overnight at 100 °C. In this typical preparation about 3 g of AC was slowly poured into the AHM solution (about 0.8 g of AHM in 3.6 mL of DI water). After the impregnation process, the material was kept at room temperature and then dried overnight at 100 °C. Then the dried sample was calcined in the tube furnace at 500 °C for 3 h under the flow of nitrogen [96]. Synthesis of low-temperature nano-crystalline molybdenum carbide was reported by Vitale, G. et al. The scheme involved AHM solution and sucrose, both were mixed in different concentrations under constant stirring. The homogenous mixture was placed in the oven and heated at 100 °C for 24 h to dry the material completely. The product was then rumpled to a fine powder and transferred to the fix bed reactor for carbonization in the inert atmosphere underflow of H2 gas. The sample was heated at different temperatures with ramp rate 15 °C/minute and temperature was maintained for the given time. When the reaction was completed, the final product was cooled to room temperature in the inert atmosphere [97]. Khabbaz, S. et al. reported a mechano-chemical synthesis of the molybdenum carbide. They took MoO3 powder as a source of Mo and synthetic graphite as a source of carbon with accurate stoichiometry and loaded into the ball mill and severely milled for various times. The whole operation was performed in the inert atmosphere under the flow of argon to prevent the material from oxidation. The milled material was treated in the tube furnace equipped with a vacuum for 1 h [98]. The stepwise mechanism is shown in the Fig. 3 . 2.2 Preparation of Mo2C hybrids with different materials A facile preparation of N, P and Co-doped molybdenum carbide hybrid was proposed by Wang, W et al. they prepared the hybrid by using phosphomolybdic acid and red dates with the ratio of 1:4. Both were added in 100 mL DI water and formed a turbid liquid. The liquid was then ultrasonicated for 30 min and transferred to 100 mL Teflon lined autoclave which was heated up to 200 °C for 24 h. After that, by suction filtration the Mo-precursor was obtained, washed with water and ethanol repetitively. Then the material was transferred to the tube furnace and heated up to 800 °C in the inert atmosphere at the ramp rate of 2 °C/minute for 3 h. After that the material was cooled down to room temperature and the final product was called N, P co-doped molybdenum carbide [99]. For fabrication of Mo2C based electrocatalyst with nitrogen-doped 3-dimensional mesoporous carbon, first the small pieces of rice paper were immersed in sulfuric acid (0.5 M) and KOH (0.5 M) for about one and a half-hour to remove the impurities. After that, the rice papers were washed with ultra-pure water repeatedly many times. The size of the rice paper was about 3 × 2.5 cm2. These blocks were immersed into about 150 mL of ammonium heptamolybdate solution for 24 h. Later the rice papers were collected and dried at 60 °C for 12 h and were calcined at 800 °C in argon inert atmosphere for 5 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute. Then the obtained catalyst was then washed with ethanol and ultra-pure water many times. Different concentrations of the products were obtained in this manner with different concentrations of ammonium heptamolybdate [100]. Another hybrid of Mo2C called Co-NC@Mo2C was synthesized by ZIF-67 which is grounded thoroughly and was mixed with AHM (Ammonium Heptamolybdate tetrahydrate). Further, annealed at 700 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute for 3 h under the high flow of pure argon gas. The obtained product was Cobalt doped nitrogen molybdenum carbide. Similarly the nitrogen carbon-doped molybdenum carbide electrocatalyst preparation was carried out by mixing the ZIF-8 with AHM and annealed at 700 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute under high purity argon for 3 h and the product obtained called NC@Mo2C [101]. Similarly for the synthesis of molybdenum hybrid with N-CNTs/Ni required a 4 g melamine, 0.05 g glucose, 0.2 g Ni(NO3)2.6H2O and about (0.01−0.08 g) Na2MoO4. All the materials were mixed and was transferred for calcination at about 800 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 2 °C/minute under the flow of high purity argon to create the inert atmosphere [39]. The schematic for the preparation of hybrid is given in Fig. 4 . For the preparation of Mo2C hybrid with nitrogen-doped sheets consist of AHM, sucrose, and g-C3N4. They were mixed in the ratio of 1:2:2 by mass and then the homogenous mixture was calcined in the tube furnace at the temperature of 800 °C under the flow of nitrogen with the ramp rate of 3 °C/minute for about 6 h. Before the calcination, the pumping and purging should be done three times with nitrogen gas. Different samples with various concentrations were prepared in the same way [102]. Similarly, for the preparation of cobalt doped hybrid of molybdenum carbide required 5 mmol CoCl2, 5 mmol Na2MoO4, and thiourea about 15 mmol were mixed under magnetic string in 80 mL DI water. The mixture was then put into 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and is locked properly. This autoclave was then kept in an oven at 180 °C for about 4 h. The reactions products were filtered out, washed, and dried at about 60 °C for 16 h. The obtained products are called CMS-Xh and X stands for a time of reaction [22]. Sufen, Wang et al. prepared a graphitic carbon shell on molybdenum carbide by iron doping for hydrogen evaluation. They first pretreated the MoS2 (10 g) and dissolved in the DI water and froze it in the refrigerator for 24 h at temperature of -20 °C. Then the suspension was collected and kept at normal temperature for complete thawing. These steps were repeated many times and after that the solution was added into the aqueous solution of FeCl3. Then the resulting mixture was mixed and heated for 24 h to evaporate the solvent completely. After that the solid precursor was subjected to the tube furnace and heated to 1000 °C under the flow of CH4-H2 mixture at the ramp rate of 8 °C/minute for 2 h to obtained the final product [103]. Another preparation of carbon-doped molybdenum carbide involved 2 mmol AHM and 36 mmol aniline was added in 3-necked round-bottom of 100 mL filled with DI water at about 40 mL of the round bottom flask. Then 1 M aqueous solution of HCL was added for controlling the pH at 4.0. Later the solution was heated at a temperature of 50 °C for about 4 h. After centrifugation, precipitate was collected and washed thoroughly with DI water and ethanol. A white powder was obtained which is dried for overnight in vacuum oven at 60 °C. The white powder was transferred to the tube furnace and which is heated at 775 °C temperature with a ramp rate of 2 °C/minute under the flow of argon to create the inert atmosphere for 2 h. The Mo-Mo2C sample was obtained and was cooled down at room temperature [1]. The synthesis of hybrid Mo2C with SrTiO3 involved Mo2C precursor material such as aqueous solution of AHM and dicyandiamide. The materials were uniformly mixed by ultra-sonication with SrTiO3 at room temperature. It increased the contact among them thus leading to a well-coated product of Mo2C on SrTiO3 after the process of calcination at 800 °C in inert atmosphere (Ar flow) for 3 h [56]. The schematic given in Fig. 5 shows the preparation scheme of the hybrid of Mo2C with SrTiO3. Another hybrid of Mo2C along with CNT-SC and Mo2C with CNT-C can be used for electrochemical water splitting. It was synthesized by a spray drying approach followed by the carbonization process. The synthesis process required AHM along with a 5 wt.% multi-wall water-based CNT conductive paste that was used as a precursor. For the optimization purposes, a fixed amount of AHM was used with different molar ratios of C/Mo 2:1, 6:1, 10:1, 14:1 and 16:1, respectively. In the start, the molar ratio of 2:1 was taken but the Mo2C cannot be detected because of a lack of carbon source. Both AHM and CNT liquefied in 500 mL DI water which was mixed for 12 h. The solution is ultra-sonicated for about 1 h which gave a homogenous suspension. Later the resulting mixture suspension was put into the spray dryer at a higher flow rate. The inlet temperature of the dryer was 180 °C and the outlet temperature was maintained at 100 °C. In the end, the black powder was collected which was carbonized in the quartz tube at about 500 °C for 1 h and 700 °C for almost 4 h along with the heating rate of 5 °C/minute in an inert atmosphere under the flow of argon to obtain Mo2C hybrid of CNT-SC. Similarly, another hybrid of Mo2C with CNT-C was synthesized by the same procedure but without the spray drying process. About 14.4 g of CNTs along with 1.06 g of AHM was added in DI water (500 mL) and stirred for about 12 h. Material was then dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C to remove the solvent followed by carbonization of the precursor powder in the inert atmosphere at the temperature of 700 °C for about 4 h as shown in the Fig. 6 [104]. A different method for the formulation of polyvinyl alcohol coated with molybdenum carbide nanospheres was reported [67]. This method depends on the carbonization of an organic ligand (melamine-formaldehyde (MF) resin nanospheres) with AHM occupying to the surface and pores of MF nanospheres. The single-source precursor comprised of both molybdenum source and carbon source which provided a better fabrication of transition metal carbides i.e. molybdenum carbide and tungsten carbide. Briefly, for the synthesis of MF nanospheres about 6 mg PVA solution along with 1.2 mL acetic acid both were added in a transparent melamine-formaldehyde solution simultaneously and stirred the solution for about 6 min at 60 °C, forming a milky suspension which was centrifuged followed by washing for several times with distill water giving melamine-formaldehyde nanospheres. For the preparation of AHM coated MF nanospheres, they were dissolved in AHM solution and then the resulting solution was filtered out, washed, and dried at 80 °C in the oven for one night. The powder was sent to the carbonization process in a tube furnace under the flow of Argon or hydrogen. The process was conducted at three different temperatures at about 550, 650 and 750 °C at the ramp rate of 5 °C/min. The resulting samples were named as molybdenum carbide nanospheres represented as Mo2C-550, PVA-Mo2C/Mo2N which was for Mo2C-650 and Mo2C 750 respectively as shown in the schematic given in Fig. 7 [105]. Another method proposed by Zou, L. et al. for the preparation of nanoporous Mo2C coated with GF. The hybrid was prepared by the facile electrostatic self-assembly which was then treated at high-temperature carbonization process. The process typically consists of treating GF pieces that were dipped in 50 mL of 10 mg/mL PDDA solution and then sonicated for 1 h. After horizontal vibrational oscillation for 12 h, the GF pieces were washed many times and immersed into 50 mL PMo12 solution with different concentrations. The GF pieces were separated, washed with DI water for several times and subsequently dried overnight at 60 °C to obtained PMo12-PDDA-GF. The obtained precursor was then carbonized at high temperature of 900 °C in an inert atmosphere under the flow of argon or hydrogen to obtain a composite of Mo2C@GF as described in Fig. 8 [106]. Chaker. S. et al. proposed another synthesis of Mo2C in which 400 g of PDDA was dissolved in DI water with constant stirring and adding dropwise solution of AHM (80 mg/mL). The solution becomes a suspension of white color because the pair of ions between PDDA and molybdate was formed. Stirred the suspension for about 1 h and then transferred to 15 mL autoclave at a high temperature of 180 °C for 12 h. The white-colored product was obtained which was dry up at 80 °C then heated at a temperature of 800 °C in the tube furnace in the inert atmosphere at a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute and obtained Mo2C@NC. Then the material was annealed at different temperature i.e. at 700 °C and 900 °C to obtain MoO2@NC and Mo2C-Mo@NC respectively [107]. Chen, J. et al. reported another method of preparation of Mo2C@NC through small size filter paper that was washed several times with ethanol and DI water which were then immersed in AHM aqueous solution with different concentrations at normal temperature for about 24 h and dried at 70 °C for 8 h. Then the product was annealed under Ar flow at 800 °C which produces a black Mo2C@NC electrode. He also reported the preparation of different electrodes of different concentrations [108]. Similarly, Li, J. et al. also proposed the preparation of Mo2C hybrid with NC by using urea and ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate of different concentrations that were dissolved in DI water and then evaporated at 100 °C with constant stirring which was dried and obtained a white precursor. The product was then annealed at 400 °C at a ramp rate of 2 °C/minute in the N2 atmosphere which further heated at 800 °C at a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute for 6 h and a black product was obtained in the end [59]. Mir, R.A. et al. reported the preparation of carbon molybdenum carbide nanopowders involving molybdenum trioxide, reducing agent magnesium and polypropylene that were mixed and transferred to autoclave. Which was put into a furnace at 600 and 700 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min. The temperature was maintained for about 15–20 h to obtain single-phase Mo2C. Then the solution was cooled down to normal temperature and the product obtained was washed with dilute HCL to remove MgO followed by washing with distilled water and with HCL. At the end the product was dried by vacuum heating at 120 °C [109]. Zhu, Y. et al. reported another way to produce Mo2C incapacitated with a graphene 3D network through the pyrolysis of molten salt through an ion exchange resin. At first, D201 was dipped into the AHM aqueous solution that exchanges the OH− ions with Mo7O24 −6 and then it was mixed in powder form with NaCl/KCl. To initiate the reaction the precursor was then heated at 800 °C in the inert atmosphere. Due to heating, NaCl/KCl was converted to form molten salt and due to carbonization of the resin Mo7O24 -6 converted to Mo2C nanocrystal. This molten salt was not only acted as heating media but also performed as pore generator in the functional carbon. In the last step, porogen removal was performed and 3D network Mo2C decorated with graphene like carbon nanosheets obtained [27]. The schematic given in Fig. 9 shows the preparation route for the synthesis of Molybdenum carbide decorated with graphene. Tang, C. et al. proposed the preparation of Mo2 (CN). For the preparation of Mo2 (CN) a known amount of melamine, cyanuric acid, Pluronic (P123) and AHM were mixed in about 50 mL DI water for 12 h. A homogenous milky mixture was formed and was then dried up at 80 °C giving a white precursor. The precursor was then placed in a tube furnace for the carbonization at 3 different temperatures i.e. 700, 750 and 800 °C with a slope rate of 2 °C/minute in the inert atmosphere to obtain Mo2(CN) [51]. Chi, J.Q. et al. described another method for preparation of Molybdenum carbide doped with nitrogen and carbon. To synthesis Mo2O4 −2, AHM was dissolved in 60 mL DI water containing triton X-100. Subsequently small amounts of aniline and pyrrole were added in the mixture and ultra-sonicated for 1 h to form a homogenous mixture. The obtained solution was then cooled for half an hour and then polymerized for 12 h at 0 °C. The acquired product was washed with DI water and ethanol and was finally dried under vacuum. The product obtained at the end was denoted by MoO4 −2 nanospheres. The obtained product was loaded in to a tube furnace and calcined at 650 °C for about 3 h with the ramp rate of 5 °C/minute to synthesize a hybrid of Mo2C@NC [110]. Ojha, K. et al. reported Mo2C rods hybridized with different concentrations of reducing graphene oxide. The synthesis was carried out in 2 main steps. At first, a known amount of rGO was dispersed ultrasonically in small quantity of AM in distilled water followed by addition of certain amount of aniline under constant stirring. Afterwards a small amount of HCl was added to maintain the pH at 3.5. The obtained mixture was then dried at 50 °C to form the precipitate of ammonium anilinium molybdate. The precipitate was then filtered out and dried at 80 °C which was then loaded in a tube furnace and heated at 750 °C for 5 h in the inert atmosphere under the flow of N2 [61]. Similarly, Li, H. et al. anticipated a method to prepare the hybrid of TiO2 with Mo2C having different concentrations by the temperature-programmed method. The synthesis involved a small amount of AHM dissolved in DI water with 1 g of anatase. TiO2 was added and the mixture was heated at 50 °C under vigorous stirring. Then the obtained sample was carbonized under the flow of CH4/H2 followed by a series of temperature-programmed processes. At first, the material was heated at 400 °C with the ramp rate of 5 °C/minute and in the second step temperature was increased up to 650 °C under different slope rate of 1 °C/minute and was maintained at this temperature for 3 h. After carbonization, the final product was cooled down to room temperature [111]. Kelly, T.G., et al. proposed a new method for the synthesis of palladium supported Mo2C hybrid containing polycrystalline W foil as a source of palladium and Mo foil as a source of Molybdenum source, that were added in DI water with methanol and dipped in the NaOH solution for about a minute to remove the oxides. These foils were then put into the furnace for the carbonization reaction in an inert atmosphere at temperature of 850 °C to 1000 °C to form Mo2C and WC respectively. After the reaction the hydrogen gas was passed to remove the excess carbon [112]. Xu, L. et al. prepared Molybdenum carbide reinforced by Al2O3, the synthesis step involved aluminum nitrate as a source of Al2O3 and MoO2 powder as a source of Mo. At first, the aluminum nitrate solution was prepared, mixed with MoO2 powder, and heated at 80 °C to get a dried precursor. The furnace was loaded with precursor and heated at 550 °C for 2 h in the inert atmosphere that decomposed the aluminum nitrate into the Al2O3 followed by heating at 980 °C for about 6−7 h to make MoO2 to MoO3 [113]. Cheng, j. et al. reported the effects of the nickel and cobalt on the Mo2C catalytic performance. They prepared the hybrid of Co, Ni-Mo with different concentrations. The preparation steps involved AHM solution in DI water as a source of Mo and cobalt or nickel nitrate hexahydrate as a source of nickel and cobalt. Both these solutions were mixed and heated at 80 °C with continuous mixing to form a viscous mixture. The mixture was then dried at 100 °C for one night to form powder material. The dried powder was subsequently loaded in a tube furnace and heated at 450 °C for 4 h in an inert atmosphere under the flow of nitrogen. The material was purged after heating at 300 °C for almost 10 min with argon gas and then transferred for the carbonization reaction under the flow of the mixture of hydrogen and methane gas through temperature-programmed reaction heated from 300 °C–700 °C at a rate of 1 °C/minute. When the reaction was completed, the product was cooled down under the flow of argon to room temperature [114]. Wu, Q. et al. reported the preparation of Mo based hybrid with AC, CNTs, and TiO2. In their synthesis scheme, first they crushed CNTs into powder and purified with nitric acid at 110 °C for almost 5 h. Secondly, the material was filtered out washed and dried. After that AHM solution was added into the individual support according to the required amounts with continuous mixing for 1 h. The sample was heated for 12−14 h at 100 °C to get the powder precursor. The precursor was then calcined under the flow of N2 at 450 °C for 2 h with a slope rate of 5 °C/minute. After that, the precursor was carbonized in the tube furnace with the temperature-programmed process under the flow of a mixture of CH4/H2. Before processing the mixture to furnace it was purged with N2 gas to make an inert atmosphere and to remove the air from the furnace. In the first stage the precursor was heated at 280 °C with a ramp rate of under 5 °C/minute, then in the second step the temperature was increased from 280 °C to 750 °C with a ramp rate of up to 1 °C/minute and was kept at that temperature for 2 h. Finally, the material was cooled to room temperature in the inert atmosphere under the flow of nitrogen. A wet impregnation step was applied for alkali modified carbide samples by using K2CO3 solution and aging for 1 h, followed by drying in an inert atmosphere. The sample was then loaded in the furnace for the calcination process at the temperature of 450 °C for 2 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute [115]. Wang, C. et al. also reported a method for the preparation of Mo2C loaded with ZrO2 by coprecipitation and impregnation method. In their experimental scheme firstly the molybdenum carbide was prepared by the dissolving ammonium heptamolybdate with hexamethylenetetramine in a ratio of 1:9 respectively in 15 % NH3.H2O solution. This method was required to impregnate ZrO2 and Zr(OH)4 in the molybdenum precursor solution in order to prepare the Mo2C/ZrO2 catalyst. The impregnated precursor was first dried at room temperature for 48 h and then in the vacuum oven for 3 h at 80 °C. The catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation of Mo2C precursor with zirconium nitrite solution. The method required systematic mixing of two solutions under constant water bath at temperature of 60 °C. After 12 h aging process, the mixture was filtered, washed, and dried at 80 °C overnight in vacuum oven. Carbonization and passivation processes were used to synthesis the catalyst. In carbonization process the precursor was heated at 700 °C for 2 h under the flow of inert atmosphere. In passivation process the samples were passivated in the mixed air for 2 h to prevent deactivation of the catalyst in the air [116]. Another hybrid of Mo2C with Al2O3 was also reported by Osman, A., et al. They synthesized Mo2C precursor using wet impregnation of alumina supports containing ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate solution. The solution was sonicated for 3 h at 80 °C to form a homogenous mixture. The mixture was then dried at 120 °C for overnight and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h under the flow of air at ramp rate of 2 °C/min. After calcination, the sample was crushed and pelletized. Finally, these pellets were carburized under the flow of mixture of H2/CH4 from room temperature to 200 °C with heating rate of 10 °C/min and then from 200 °C to 590 °C at the heating rate of 1 °C/min and were kept this temperature constant for 2 h [117]. 3 Electrocatalytic parameters In this section, we have discussed the electrochemical parameters of the Mo2C, and its hybrids reported in the literature. For the better understanding of HER mechanism from Kinetic point of view, the Tafel slopes is determined by using the following equation i.e. (13) ή = b l o g j + a where j is called the current density and b is called Tafel slope [118]. A smaller Tafel slope indicates a lower overpotential value with increased current density. Thus, enhancing the HER efficiency of the catalyst. HER reaction involves 2 steps. The first step is called the Volmer reaction in which the electrochemical adsorption of hydrogen occurs. The second step is called the Tafel reaction and the desorption of absorbed hydrogen takes place in this step [119]. These reactions are described as under. i Electrochemical Adsorption of hydrogen (14) H+ + M + e− → M−H** ii Electrochemical Desorption of Hydrogen (15) M-H* + H+ + e− → M + H2 For HER the Tafel slope is the rate-determining step. If the Tafel slope of the certain reaction is 120 mVdec−1 then it indicates that Volmer reaction is the rate-determining step [120–122]. In this section, we have discussed the Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy for different catalysts to study their HER kinetics. The active sites of the catalysts are determined by the doubled-layered capacitance which was calculated from the cyclic voltammetry. The stability of the catalyst is an important parameter for determining the efficiency of the catalyst. In this paper, the stability of the different catalysts has been reported which have been synthesized by different methods [123]. 3.1 Tafel slope Tafel slopes can be obtained from LSV curves and reflects the electrochemical kinetics that correlates the reaction rate to the overpotential. An ideal catalyst for water splitting should have a low Tafel slope and high current density [47]. In this section, we have mentioned the Tafel slopes of different catalysts synthesized by different techniques and precursors. Zh, Xia. et al. have reported that Mo2C-0.4 showed the Tafel slope of 48 mV dec−1 which was the lowest as compared to the other prepared samples at different concentrations i.e. Mo2C-0 and Mo2C-0.2 [87]. Xing, J. et al. have reported that the Mo2C-0.01 sample showed the smallest Tafel slope of about 66.5 mV dec−1 as compared to the other prepared samples synthesized at different carbonization temperatures as seen in the Fig. 10 [88]. Authors determined that the electrochemical hydrogen desorption was the rate-determining step of the HER reaction [124]. They also have reported the Tafel slope for OER about 70 mVdec−1 which was smallest among other prepared samples at different concentrations depicting its enhanced OER activity [88]. Another electrochemical result reported by An, kaili et al. for Mo based hybrid i.e. Mo2C@3DNMC in acidic medium. The Tafel slope was found to be 88 mVdec−1 in the alkaline solution which was the smallest among various other samples [100]. Liang, Q. et al. reported a hybrid of MOF with Molybdenum carbide in the alkaline medium. They compared the Tafel slopes of different samples and found that the Co-NC@Mo2C showed the lowest value of about 65 mV dec−1 at the same current density of 10 mA cm-2. They also have discussed that the material has the best activity in the acidic medium with a very low Tafel slope value of about 60 mVdec−1 as shown in the Fig. 11 given below. The OER activity of the above-mentioned hybrid was also examined and found the Tafel slope of 61 mVdec−1 in alkaline medium. This was the lowest midst all other prepared samples at different concentrations and temperatures as shown in the Fig. 12 [101]. Electrochemical property of another hybrid of Mo2C named N-CNTs/NiS2@Mo2C was reported by Wang, J.Y., et al. The Tafel slope for OER was 77.5 mVdec−1 in alkaline media and was lowest among other prepared samples as shown in the Fig. 13 [39]. They also investigated the performance of the catalyst for the HER and found a very low Tafel slope of 114.6 mV dec−1 as given in Fig. 14 [39]. The Tafel slope of a hybrid of Mo2C with graphitic carbon nitride was reported by Dong, Jie et al. and found to be of 55 mV dec−1 in an acidic media for HER. Authors also reported that the high activity of the catalyst was due to strong influence of proton reduction [1,125]. Hu, Yang et al. examined a hybrid of Mo2C/CNT-SC for HER in the acidic solution and determined the Tafel slope to be of 53.5 mVdec−1 which was the lowest among other prepared samples. They also found that the approach for the synthesis of the materials performed an essential function in the higher activity of hydrogen production [104,126]. Another hybrid of Mo2C was prepared by Chen, X. et al. named PVA-Mo2C. They prepared another composite with Mo2N called PVA-Mo2C/Mo2N and determined the Tafel slope of their catalyst to be of 51.8 mVdec−1. That was much smaller than the other reported catalyst and was closer to the Pt/C with the Tafel slope of 30.3 mVdec−1 [105,127]. They further examined the performance of the catalyst in the alkaline medium and reported the lowest Tafel slope than in the acidic medium i.e. 50.4 mVdec−1 [105,128]. Li, T. et al. prepared a Pd supported Mo2C hybrid and tested the performance of the catalyst in the acidic as well as in the alkaline medium for both ORR and HER mechanism. The Tafel slope of their catalyst for ORR in the basic medium was calculated to be of 63.9 mVdec−1. This low value of the Tafel slope was due to palladium nanoparticles. The catalyst have higher activity due to the presence of Molybdenum in it [89,129]. For the HER they calculated the Tafel slope of the catalyst was 51 mV dec−1 that indicated the fast mechanism of the reaction. This fast mechanism was due to the higher amount of Pd in the catalyst [89,130]. The Tafel slope of Mo2C@GF composite was reported by Zou, Long. et al. for HER in both acidic and basic medium. They found the Tafel slope of the catalyst was 54 mV dec−1 and 62 mV dec−1 in the acidic and alkaline medium, respectively [106]. They determined that HER mechanism for their catalyst was governed by Volmer HER mechanism [106,131]. Chakra, Suk. et al. reported a catalyst named as Mo2C@NC and tested the performance of the catalyst for the HER in both acidic and basic medium. They reported the Tafel slope of their catalyst to be 61 mVdec−1 and 56 mV dec−1 in the acidic and basic medium, respectively. They also concluded that the catalyst showed good performance in the alkaline medium than in the acidic medium [107,132]. Further catalysts are discussed in the Table 1 . 3.2 Overpotential Overpotential is defined as the extra potential which is more than the equilibrium potential required to initiate the reaction of the catalysts for both HER and OER. Usually, the overpotential is calculated at a given current density to evaluate the activity of the electrode. Smaller the overpotential higher will be the electrochemical activity of the catalyst [47]. Here we have reported the overpotential of the Mo2C and its hybrids synthesized by the various techniques. The overpotential of pure Mo2C was 100 mV and was reported by Zh, Xia. et al. That was the best among other samples which was due to the appropriate composite between the α-Mo2C and β-Mo2C improving the intrinsic catalytic activity [87]. Xing, J. et al. investigated and reported that the Mo2C-0.1 sample gave the lowest overpotential of about 130 mV versus the reversible hydrogen electrode at the current density of 10 mAcm−2. They also investigated the overpotential for OER which was about 274 mV at the current density of 10 mAcm−2. That was the smallest other than the described OER catalysts as shown in the Fig. 15 [88]. An, Kaili et al. reported the overpotential of a Mo based hybrid called Mo2C@3DNMC in both alkaline and acidic medium. In alkaline medium, the overpotential was found to be 76 mV. However, 102 mV was reported in the acidic medium. That was the lowest of all prepared hybrid at different temperatures and concentrations [100]. Another hybrid investigated by Liang, Q. et al. with the overpotential of 173 mV at the current density of 10 mAcm−2. They also examined the activity of the catalyst in the acid medium and found that due to the corrosive nature of the Co nanoparticles, the HER activity of this catalyst was not so good in the acidic medium [101,133]. For this purpose, they covered Co particles by the Mo2C and then tested it in the acidic medium resulted good activity in it. They found the overpotential of about 143 mV which was much better than the other reported catalyst in the acidic medium as shown in the Fig. 16 [101,134]. Another hybrid of Mo2C named as N-CNTs/NiS2@Mo2C was studied by Wang, J. et al. and they reported its overpotential for OER was 320 mV at the current density of 10 mAcm−2. However, for HER was about 260 mV as shown in the Fig. 17 . They found that the astronomical activity of the catalyst was due to a high active valence intermediate state of Ni and S at low voltage [39,135]. The overpotential of Mo2C/CNT-SC was conveyed by Hu, Yang., et al. that exhibited a low value of 112 mV in the acidic medium vs RHE at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 [104,136]. Chen, Xia et al. reported the overpotential of PVA-Mo2C/Mo2N for HER in the acidic medium with a very small value of 132 mV at the current density of 10 mA/cm2, which was very good for the water-splitting process. This high activity of the catalyst was due to the combination of the large active sites of both Mo2C and Mo2N. Furthermore, it can be ascribed to the high ECSA of the reported catalyst [105,137]. They also reported the HER kinetics in the basic/alkaline medium of their catalyst and determined the overpotential in the alkaline medium to be 142 mV [105,138]. Similarly, the overpotential of the Pd-Mo2C catalyst was reported by Li, T. et al. which for HER mechanism was 28 mV in the acidic medium. The smaller value of overpotential showed maximum hydrogen production was due to the presence of Pd in higher amounts [89]. The overpotential of Mo2C@GF was evaluated by Zou, Long, et al. for HER in both acidic and alkaline medium. They reported the overpotential to be 69 mV in acidic and almost 65 mV in the alkaline medium at the current density of about 10 mA/cm2. Performance of their catalyst for HER in the neutral solution found to be more than that of both acidic and alkaline medium and comparable with the previously reported catalysts [106,139]. Chakra, Suk. et al. reported a catalyst of Mo2C@NC and examined the performance of their catalyst for HER. They found the overpotential of their catalyst to be 135 mV in the acidic medium and 121 mV in the basic medium at the current density of 10 mAcm−2 [107]. 3.3 Durability The durability of the catalysts has been discussed in this paper as reported in the literature by different researchers. The durability of the catalyst reported by the Zh, Xia et al. was almost 5000 cycles form voltage of 0.1 V to −0.4 V at 50 mVs−1. This Mo2C-0.4 exhibits higher durability and high active sites also producing hydrogen at 20 mA cm-2 for almost 30 h [87]. Xing, J. et al. investigated the durability of the Mo2C-0.01 was about to be 20 h for HER as shown below in the Fig. 18 . They also showed that the TEM and SEM of the sample after the durability test did not affect the structure [88]. An, Kaili. et al. performed the durability test for the Mo hybrid i.e. Mo2C@3DNMC in the acidic medium and found a significant result for HER application to be 2000 cycles for 10 h. They also examined that after 10 h the structure and morphology of the material remained the same which determined the stability of the sample [100]. Similarly, another hybrid of Mo was reported by Liang, Q. et al. i.e. Co-NC@Mo2C. They experimented to check the stability of the catalyst and found it to be 1000 cycles for 25 has given in the Fig. 19 . They also experimented with the OER in the acidic medium and found for 1000 cycles the activity of the catalyst was about 10 h [101]. Wang, J. et al. reported the durability of their catalyst under three different current density and found that the catalyst can catalyze for about 20 h. They also examined the structure and morphology of the catalyst after the durability test and found that the structure and morphology remained the same [39]. The stability test of Mo2C/CNT-SC was reported by Hu, Yang et al. which is a crucial parameter that reflects the activity of the catalyst. They reported the durability of their catalyst showed negligible current decay after the 1000 cycles for over more than 30 h. They examined the morphology and the structure of the as received catalyst after the test, which showed the high stability of the catalyst [104]. Chen, Xia et al. reported the durability test of PVA-Mo2C/Mo2N in the acidic environment after the 1000 cycles and indicated that the catalyst had nominal stability for HER mechanism [105]. Similarly, the durability Pd-Mo2C was discussed by Li, T., et al. for both ORR and HER. They reported a very high durable stability of the catalyst in the acidic as well as in the basic medium [89]. The durability test of the Mo2C@GF was performed by Zou, long. et al. and reported by taking continuous potential cycling at the scan rate of 100 mV sec−1 for 1000–3000 cycles both for acidic and basic medium. They concluded that the stability of their catalyst in the acidic medium was more than 24 h and is more stable in acidic medium as compared to alkaline medium [106]. Chakra, Suk., et al. tested the durability of the Mo2C@NC and concluded that for 1000 cycles the catalyst did show any voltage drop for about 10 h in both acidic and basic medium. They also reported that the catalyst retained the current density for 10 h in both mediums [107]. 3.4 Electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) In this section, the active sites of the catalyst have been discussed that is determined by calculating the doubled layered capacitance (Cdl) obtained from the CV at different scan rates. The Cdl of the Mo2C reported by Zh, Xia, et al. was about 355.25 m F cm−2 which was almost 3–4 times more than the other prepared samples [87]. The sample reported by Xing, J. et al. had a very high number of active sites that was calculated in terms of double-layered capacitance and was about to be 35.08 m Fcm−2 which was much higher than the other prepared samples at different temperatures as shown in Fig. 20 [88]. An, Kaili et al. examined the Mo based Hybrid called Mo2C@3DNMC. They determined the active sites by calculating the Cdl. That is an important parameter for calculating the activity of the catalyst. They calculated the Cdl from the CV curves directly [140]. They reported the Cdl of Mo based hybrid was 11.56 m Fcm−2which was very much larger than the other hybrid prepared at different temperatures [100]. The active sites of the N, P co-doped Mo2C hybrid was calculated by Wang, W., et al. which they obtained from CV curves. The ECSA was calculated by measuring the doubled layered capacitance which was about to be 31.5 m F cm−2 and was higher than the prepared samples at different temperatures [99]. Another hybrid was tested by Liang, Q. et al. named Co-NC@Mo2C. They determined the active sites of the catalysts also by calculating the Cdl which was about 85.82 mFcm−2 and was stable with enhanced HER performance [101]. Wang, J. et al. reported the active sites of their catalyst by measuring the Cdl of N-CNTs/NiS2@Mo2C was to be 19.17 mFcm−2. That was higher than the other reported samples. They found that the increase in the Cdl was due to the introduction of S and Ni in the Mo-catalyst [39]. They also discussed that due to addition of the Sulfur ion increased the active site of the catalyst and by combining the S sites with Ni optimized the hydrogen adsorption capability of the catalyst [39,141]. The active site of Mo2C/CNT-SC was reported by Hu, Yang et al. They measured the doubled layered capacitance from the CV test and found the value of Cdl was about 20.08 m F/cm2. They further expressed that these enlarged active sites provided a fast movement of the reactant and favored the HER mechanism [104]. The electrochemical surface area of the Mo2C@GF was calculated by the Zou, long et al. They measured the Cdl using scan-rate dependence of CV methods which is the typical method for calculating the ECSA. The Cdl was calculated to be 35 m Fcm−2 of Mo2C@GF composite electrode which was very much higher than the mixture of Mo2C and GF [106,142]. Chakra, Suk., et al. reported the performance of Mo based hybrid named Mo2C@NC in both acidic and alkaline solution and estimated the ECSA of their catalyst by measuring its doubled layered capacitance and concluded that the active sites of the Mo2C@NC had 3–4 times more than the Mo2C-Mo@NC. They showed that the due active surface of the catalyst favored the HER mechanism [107]. The active surface area of Molybdenum carbide N doped (Mo2C@NC) nanoparticles was also calculated in both acidic and basic medium by Chen, J., et al. They manipulated the double layered capacitance of 11.56 m F.cm−2 that was quite higher than the other prepared electrodes providing the greater active area for the HER reaction. They also compared there results with the reported Mo based electrocatalyst an found that the three dimensional mesoporous matrix represented by Mo2C@NC showed the best and excellent HER activity [75,108]. Li, J., et al. reported another the electrochemical active surface area of the Molybdenum carbide N-doped carbon hybrid for HER activity. They observed it by calculating the double layered capacitance. They found that the Cdl Mo2C@NC-160 was estimated to be 50.4 m F.cm−2 which was higher than the other prepared samples at different temperature which indicated that higher HER performance of Mo2C@NC-160 could be linked with high electrochemical active surface area [59]. Another molybdenum-based hybrid influenced by graphitic carbon was studied by Mir, R.A., et al. It was performed by measuring the Cdl CV analysis performed in the voltage range of 0.2−0.4 V with different scan rates. They reported that the Cdl value of Mo2C R-600/17 was estimated to be 35.5 m F cm-2 which was higher than the other reported samples and was responsible for the higher HER mechanism. They also reported that the higher ECSA was responsible for higher current density and lower Tafel slope that was examined in the LSV and Tafel slope measurements [109]. Another graphene influenced Mo2C based hybrid was investigated by Zhu, G., et al. and reported the electrochemical active surface area by measuring the double layered capacitance and estimated to be 13 m F cm−2 in the alkaline solution [27]. Similarly, the electrochemically active surface area of Mo2 (CN) was calculated by measuring the Cdl. The continuous CV analysis in the voltage range of 0.2−0.3 V was performed. They reported the Cdl value to be 14.4 m Fcm−2 for Mo2 (CN) which was higher due to the result of the strong coupling effect of the two-phase materials [51,143]. Chi, J-Q., et.al investigated another hybrid of Mo2C denoted as Mo2C@NC@MoSx and estimated the ECSA by calculating the double layered capacitance deriving from the CV analysis. They estimated the capacitance in the acidic medium was 1.16 mFcm−2 which was higher than the other prepared samples. They also reported that this higher surface was due to the unique sandwich like structure of the material giving higher porosity [110]. 4 Conclusions and annotations Summarizing this review hydrogen is one of the most favorable fuels that can fulfill the energy requirements of the future. For this purpose, many catalysts have been synthesized for electrolytic production of hydrogen. Because of the high active sites and the same property just like the noble metals, Mo2C and its hybrids have been reported as the most auspicious catalyst for hydrogen production. It is thought Mo2C can provide a good platform to produce hydrogen used for future potential. In this review, we have comprehensively reported the preparation methods and recent progress on Mo2C and its hybrids as electrocatalyst for HER mechanism. The morphologies and HER performance of the Mo2C catalysts that are prepared by different approaches are discussed and compared in detail. Following conclusions have been made from the current researches on Mo2C and its hybrids which are used as a catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction. 1 The physicochemical properties of Mo2C and its hybrids can be enhanced by optimizing the synthesis route and carbon precursor that affects the size, shape, surface area, crystal structure, and surface state. It is observed that higher surface area Mo2C with good crystal structure can be obtained through the solid-state reaction method. 2 It is seen that the Molybdenum carbide and its hybrids prepared from temperature reduction methods in the inert atmosphere have shown the best catalytic activity than the other preparation methods. For these catalysts, doping of the other metals influenced surface area, crystal structures and the loading of these hybrids can also enhance the electronic configuration by creating a strong interaction between the metal and Mo2C. 3 The HER activity and high physiochemical stability grant Molybdenum carbide with outstanding performance specifically in an acidic medium which have evolved from the state-of-the-art transition metal catalyst. 4 By comparing the pure Mo2C with metal loaded Mo2C, it is observed that the lower temperature activity and stability were increased by loading another transition metal on molybdenum carbide. Particularly carbon-based materials like graphene and some other materials like nitrogen doped Mo2C have shown significant results for HER mechanism. 5 The unique nanostructures that are present in the hybrids of Mo2C catalysts are responsible for high catalyst activity. Such as Pd doped Mo2C, carbon-doped, and many other materials have shown the higher catalytic activity for HER and ORR mechanism. The characterization of these hybrids indicates the formation of these structures due to the strong support of the doped metal and the active sites of the molybdenum carbide. 6 From the above discussion and evaluation, it has been concluded that the pure Mo2C prepared by the Zh, Xia et al. has exhibited the best durability of about 30 h, lowest Tafel slope and the lowest overpotential which were considered to be the main parameters for the electrochemical studies. Comparing in the reported Mo2C hybrids, the hybrid synthesized by Hu, Yang et al. with CNTs showed the best electrochemical properties with highest durability of 35 h, lowest Tafel slope and lowest overpotential. These are the best Mo2C based catalyst that can be used for the electrochemical water splitting. Though the unique and interesting surface ability, structure and reactivity of Mo2C and its hybrid have been reported, yet several issues and challenges still persist for the upcoming generation for HER mechanism that needs to be addressed. The first thing that needs to be studied is the active sites of Molybdenum carbide and other transition metals catalysts for HER mechanism mainly for hydrogen evolution, adsorption, and diffusion on the catalyst surface. It is also necessary to understand the relation between HER mechanism and stoichiometry of Mo, C, and other metals. Furthermore, the activity of the electrocatalytic HER mechanism for Mo2C is still too low for the practical applications. Some modifications reported high performance HER activity created on the Molybdenum carbide structures, but high stoichiometric ratio is the disadvantage which lessens the affordability with noble metals such as Pt-based catalysts for applied purpose. Another thing important for large scale application that needs to be focused is the exposure of the active sites for improving the HER performance. Although, the present findings still barely reassured the demands due to less activity of the catalyst, yet many important results with high electrochemical activity have been reported. Therefore, it is need of time to combine experimental studies with simulations, except relying the HER performance on the crystal size, phase, proportion, and deposition. This concludes the foundation of high activity and potential synergetic effects that may provide a base for the development of new electrocatalyst of Mo2C for hydrogen production. coredata.dc:description: The world is using lot of fossil fuels due to increase in energy demand. This results in high production of CO2 which is the main reason for global warming and harmful for the environment. These issues have driven the scientists to develop environment friendly alternative energies to replace these harmful fuels. Hydrogen has become one of the most promising fuels which are environment friendly and sustainable. To produce this green and clean source of energy, electrochemical water splitting has become one of the most suitable routes. For the efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) an active catalyst is required to achieve high conversion efficiency. Many catalysts have been reported in the literature for hydrogen production through different methods. But Molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) has attracted a lot of attention and attraction to produce hydrogen through HER due to its high surface activity and electrochemical properties. In this review, the recent research progress has been reported on the Mo2C for HER mechanism. Different methods for the synthesis of Mo2C and its hybrid has been discussed extensively, along with different strategies to modify the physicochemical properties of Mo2C and its hybrid. Furthermore, the application of Mo2C related to its activity, durability, activation, and deactivation mechanism of the catalyst are critically reviewed. It is concluded that by the addition of another component in Mo2C can enhance the activity of the catalyst and gives more conversion rate. Hence, it realizes that Mo2C certainly can be used as an alternative catalyst for hydrogen production via water splitting.
coredata.dc:title: An inclusive review on the synthesis of molybdenum carbide and its hybrids as catalyst for electrochemical water splitting
